quote: When you say that, do you mean the farm side or the [org name]? I think the [org name]. [org name] is 3 farmers, we all grow potatoes. We are all selling individually, and what we’re trying to do is come together to make an organisation basically, where all our potatoes are bought centrally and marketed all together. This organization is designed to streamline the process, allowing us to work collectively rather than as isolated entities. So, fundamentally, we brought in a trader to take the burden out of the individual farms and get closer to the customers, because the customers don’t really want to deal with the farms; they would rather go through an organization. This setup acts as an interface between the farmers and the customers, ensuring that the organization is owned by the farmers and tailored to their needs.

Initially, we had to go through other channels outside of [org name], which meant a significant portion of the profits was absorbed by the middleman. Our primary goal is to eliminate this intermediary, ensuring that all the money that would typically go to them is redirected back to the farmers. We are not focused on generating profit for ourselves; instead, our mission is to ensure that the financial benefits are passed directly to the farmers. This is a fundamental issue in the agricultural industry—money is not reaching the farmers as it should. The lack of financial return to farmers is a critical problem we aim to address through our organization.

The organization, referred to as [org name], consists of three farmers who specialize in potato cultivation. Their primary activity is to collaborate in marketing and selling their potatoes collectively, rather than individually. By centralizing the buying and selling process, they aim to eliminate the traditional middleman, thereby increasing the profits that return to the farmers. The organization employs a trader to manage the supply chain, ensuring a steady flow of potatoes to factories and customers. This approach not only simplifies the process for customers, who prefer dealing with an organization rather than individual farms, but also enhances the farmers' ability to meet market demands efficiently. Overall, [org name] serves as a vital interface between the farmers and the market, focusing on sustainability and fair pricing for their produce.

In terms of collaborators, the organization currently works with three direct farms that supply potatoes, along with other contractual farms that guarantee their produce to the group. This collaborative network is essential for maintaining a consistent supply of potatoes to major factories such as Walkers, McCains, and Seabrooks, as well as providing pre-packaged products for supermarkets like Morrison’s. The organization’s role is to bypass the traditional middle man, ensuring that the profits from sales are directed back to the farmers, thereby supporting their livelihoods and promoting a more sustainable agricultural model.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on [org name], as highlighted by the sudden disruption of contracts with customers. With the food sector, particularly restaurants, ceasing operations overnight, the organization found itself unable to move the required tonnage of potatoes. This situation left a significant amount of produce without a market, illustrating the precarious nature of the agricultural supply chain. The speaker notes that approximately one third of the potato industry is dependent on this sector, underscoring the scale of the challenge faced by [org name] and the urgency to adapt to these unforeseen circumstances.
We are all selling individually, and what we’re trying to do is come together to make an organisation basically, where all our potatoes are bought centrally and marketed all together.
the idea was that we cut out the middle man and all that money comes back to the farm.
we supply factories like Walkers, McCains, Seabrooks – various crisps, all those sorts of people.
our customers basically tore up in front of us. For supply, we’ve basically not been able to move the tonnage required.
we had a lot of potatoes sat there with no homes.

We buy from other farms as well, which supply at different times of year, it varies. This allows us to maintain a steady supply of potatoes throughout the year, regardless of seasonal fluctuations. While our main operations are local, we do engage with factories and suppliers nationally. Additionally, we have occasionally exported to countries like Poland, Ireland, and Belgium, particularly when there is a surplus or when local supply is affected by extreme weather conditions. This flexibility in sourcing is crucial for meeting the demands of our customers and ensuring that we can provide potatoes all year round.

The organization primarily focuses on local and national supply chains, but they also engage in international trade when market conditions necessitate it. As mentioned, "But that’s not a regular thing, that’s just when the market requires it, if there’s an opportunity we have to grab it." This reflects their strategy of being responsive to market demands, allowing them to export surplus potatoes to countries like Poland, Ireland, and Belgium when local supply exceeds demand. This adaptability is crucial for maintaining a steady flow of business and ensuring that they can meet the needs of their customers throughout the year.

When you say that, do you mean the farm side or the [org name]? I think the [org name]. [org name] is 3 farmers, we all grow potatoes. We are all selling individually, and what we’re trying to do is come together to make an organisation basically, where all our potatoes are bought centrally and marketed all together. This organization is designed to streamline the process, allowing us to work collectively rather than as isolated entities. So, fundamentally, we brought in a trader to take the burden out of the individual farms and get closer to the customers, because the customers don’t really want to deal with the farms; they would rather go through an organization. This setup acts as an interface between the farmers and the customers, ensuring that the organization is owned by the farmers and tailored to their needs.

The organization operates on a national scale, supplying factories across the country with potatoes. To ensure a steady supply throughout the year, they purchase potatoes from various regions on an ad hoc basis, accommodating the different harvesting periods. This strategy is vital for meeting the continuous demand from factories, as both the organization and the factories rely on a reliable year-round supply of potatoes.

The organization operates on multiple levels: locally, regionally, and nationally, ensuring a robust supply chain for its potato products. However, it also has the capability to engage in international trade when necessary. For instance, during periods of surplus, the organization has successfully exported potatoes to countries like Poland, Ireland, and Belgium. This strategic approach not only helps manage excess inventory but also allows the organization to tap into broader markets, thereby enhancing its overall operational resilience.
So, we buy from other farms as well, which supply at different times of year, it varies.
But that’s not a regular thing, that’s just when the market requires it, if there’s an opportunity we have to grab it.
So, fundamentally, we brought in a trader to take the burden out of the individual farms and get closer to the customers.
And obviously, we want to supply the factories all year round, and they want a supply all year round.
Yeah, when there are too many potatoes here, we have exported to Poland, exported to Ireland and Belgium quite a bit.

Yes, as it were. I’ve just obeyed the company really. We’ve got a lot to do, to get to where we want to get to. It’s certainly helping. Obviously, after Covid it’s been a challenging year. So, people have seen that it’s a good idea and they want in on it? Yes, there’s more competition in the area.

This segment illustrates the impact of [org name]'s strategy on the local agricultural market. By cutting out the middleman and centralizing the purchasing and marketing of potatoes, they have created a more competitive environment. The speaker acknowledges that their efforts have prompted other organizations to merge and adapt, indicating a shift in the market dynamics. This competition is seen as a positive development, suggesting that the organization's model is gaining traction and encouraging others to rethink their approaches to potato distribution and sales.

The speaker acknowledges that while [org name] could potentially contribute to developing processing capacity, financial limitations pose a significant barrier. They emphasize that substantial investment is required for such initiatives, but current profit margins in agriculture are insufficient to support this. The banking industry's withdrawal from agricultural financing further complicates the situation, making it difficult for organizations like [org name] to secure the necessary funds to invest in processing capabilities. This highlights the critical need for financial support and investment in the agricultural sector to foster growth and sustainability.
We are all selling individually, and what we’re trying to do is come together to make an organisation basically, where all our potatoes are bought centrally and marketed all together.
the idea was that we cut out the middle man and all that money comes back to the farm.
the money going back to farmers – that’s what’s not been happening?
there’s more competition in the area.
the trouble with all these ideas is that they cost a lot of money.

Yes, so what you’re saying is that if a supplier dropped out, you could find a different supplier, and things like that? Yes, obviously the crucial thing is suppliers and farmers. If you haven’t got them, or enough of them to supply the demand you’ve got, you’ve got problems. So, they’re the important ones? Yes. This exchange illustrates the foundational role that suppliers and farmers play in ensuring the organization can meet its commitments and maintain its operations effectively. Without a reliable network of suppliers, the organization risks falling short in fulfilling customer demands, which could jeopardize its stability and growth.

The crucial players in the functioning of [org name] include the direct suppliers, which are the three farms that form the core of the organization, as well as other contracted farms that guarantee a steady supply of potatoes. While these suppliers are essential for meeting demand, the day-to-day management and operational decisions are primarily handled by the management team, which includes the speaker. This structure allows [org name] to maintain flexibility in sourcing and ensures that the organization can adapt to changes in supply and demand effectively.

Yeah, that’s me, we’re the crucial ones. This statement underscores my role in the organization, where I manage the day-to-day operations and ensure that everything runs smoothly. Without our efforts, the organization wouldn't be able to function effectively, especially in coordinating the supply of potatoes from various farms to meet market demands. Our focus is on maximizing returns for the farmers and ensuring a steady supply chain, which is vital for the sustainability of our operations.

If you haven’t got them, or enough of them to supply the demand you’ve got, you’ve got problems. So, they’re the important ones? Yes.
There’s three farms that are direct suppliers, and then we have contractual other farms, basically guaranteeing us their spuds, contracted into the group.

We want more growers on board, more customers, and to grow that base we’d need to add more of what we’re doing and probably streamline what we’re doing. This reflects our commitment to enhancing our operational efficiency and expanding our reach within the agricultural market. So, there’s a three-way approach where we can drive out the inefficiencies, really. Additionally, as you know, things have changed quite recently – can you see any trends in society that could perhaps accelerate the vision that you’ve just put forward, that might contribute to help? This question highlights our awareness of the broader market landscape and our desire to leverage societal shifts to bolster our growth strategy.

The speaker envisions a future where sustainability is paramount in the food system. They aim to expand their organization by bringing more farmers on board, thereby increasing the collective benefits for all members. A key initiative is the introduction of a 7.5kg bag line, which represents a step towards getting closer to the customer and reducing dependency on factories. This approach is intended to create a more direct supply chain, ultimately allowing for a process that delivers produce straight from the farm to the end customer. By doing so, they hope to enhance profitability for farmers and ensure that the financial benefits of their work are maximized.

The speaker articulates that sustainability in their operations hinges on achieving fair pricing for their products. They note that while customers are willing to pay a fair price for quality, the market is currently skewed by middlemen and factories that drive prices down, making it difficult for farmers to break even. The speaker emphasizes the need to move closer to the end product to stabilize prices, as they have experienced a significant drop in base prices over the past two years. They assert that to cover costs, farmers need to receive £100-£110 per tonne, contrasting sharply with the current market prices of £30-£40 per tonne. This situation underscores the importance of restructuring the supply chain to ensure that farmers can charge fair prices while remaining profitable.

The organization is not just focused on selling raw potatoes; it is exploring innovative ways to add value to its products. By slicing potatoes and potentially creating ready-made meals, the organization aims to cater directly to consumer preferences, thereby bypassing traditional distribution channels. This direct-to-consumer approach is a strategic move to enhance profitability and ensure that more of the revenue generated from sales goes back to the farmers, aligning with their goal of sustainability and reducing the influence of middlemen in the supply chain.
We are all selling individually, and what we’re trying to do is come together to make an organisation basically, where all our potatoes are bought centrally and marketed all together.
Sustainability is the key to anything. If we don’t have sustainability, we’ve got problems.
The closer to the customer we get, the more we’ll get back to the farm.
We need to move closer to the end product where we can sustain a steady, average price for sustainability.
I think rather than just selling the potato, we’ll slice it, and things like that.

The speaker is emphasizing the critical need for the UK to enhance its manufacturing capacity to process locally grown potatoes. Currently, a significant amount of potatoes is imported for ready-made meals, despite having ample domestic supply. The investment in processing facilities has largely gone abroad, leading to a situation where UK-grown potatoes are sent to countries like Belgium for processing and then returned as finished products. This not only raises costs but also contributes to unnecessary road miles, which is environmentally unsustainable. The speaker questions the logic behind this practice and advocates for a shift towards utilizing local resources more effectively.

The speaker acknowledges that while [org name] could potentially contribute to developing processing capacity, financial limitations pose a significant barrier. They emphasize that substantial investment is required for such initiatives, but current profit margins in agriculture are insufficient to support this. The banking industry's withdrawal from agricultural financing further complicates the situation, making it difficult for organizations like [org name] to secure the necessary funds to invest in processing capabilities. This highlights the critical need for financial support and investment in the agricultural sector to foster growth and sustainability.

The speaker recognizes the pressing issues within the agricultural sector, stating, "I can see the issue. I know exactly what the issue is and I know where you’d take it forward." However, they feel limited in their ability to effect change due to a lack of investment, saying, "without the investment or money to back what requires doing, it’s a waste of time." They then discuss the stability of their organization, noting, "The stability in [org name] is fine," but contrasting this with the "disastrous" state of agriculture, emphasizing that without farmers and a reliable supply of potatoes, their organization cannot maintain stability. This highlights the critical need for financial support and investment in the agricultural sector to ensure its resilience and sustainability.

The speaker envisions a future where sustainability is paramount in the food system. They aim to expand their organization by bringing more farmers on board, thereby increasing the collective benefits for all members. A key initiative is the introduction of a 7.5kg bag line, which represents a step towards getting closer to the customer and reducing dependency on factories. This approach is intended to create a more direct supply chain, ultimately allowing for a process that delivers produce straight from the farm to the end customer. By doing so, they hope to enhance profitability for farmers and ensure that the financial benefits of their work are maximized.

The discussion reveals that the processing capacity in the UK is a significant bottleneck for the agricultural sector. Despite having a robust supply of farmers and potatoes, the inability to process these products locally means that much of the potential output is wasted or exported for processing abroad. This situation is exacerbated by the current economic climate, where investment in local processing facilities is lacking. The speaker points out that without adequate processing capabilities, the farming industry cannot thrive, leading to a cycle of inefficiency and financial instability. Addressing this bottleneck is crucial for the future sustainability of the agricultural sector in the UK.

So, it’s about developing manufacturing capacity to actually use what we already have? We use what here, we import a large amount of potatoes anyway, for ready-made meals and things like that. We’ve got the product to use, it’s here in the country but we’re not utilising it.
The trouble with all these ideas is that they cost a lot of money. And at a farm level, there isn’t a lot of money left in the tank to be able to chuck at these things.
Without the investment or money to back what requires doing, it’s a waste of time, isn’t it?
I think sustainability is the key to anything. If we don’t have sustainability, we’ve got problems.
The closer to the customer we get, the more we’ll get back to the farm.

Now I’m in my late 30’s (nearly 40!), I should really be pushing things on. Yeah, building things up, developing them, yeah. However, the reality is that I’m doing quite the opposite. Due to the current challenges in the agricultural sector, I find myself scaling back my operations. From the [org name] point of view, I’m focusing on getting more growers on board and spreading the risk out to more growers. This way, the more growers we have, the less at risk we are, allowing us to navigate the uncertainties of the market more effectively.

The speaker highlights the difficulties banks face in lending to businesses with negative cash flow, a situation exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic. They express concern that many businesses will find themselves in similar predicaments. In response to these challenges, the speaker has devised a contingency plan for their farming operations, which involves reducing the scale of their activities. This decision is driven by the need to minimize financial risk and ensure that their operations remain viable in an unpredictable market.

The speaker emphasizes that on the organizational side, they can mitigate risk by diversifying and bringing in more growers. This strategy allows them to spread the risk across a broader base, ensuring that they are not overly reliant on a limited number of suppliers. Conversely, on the farm side, the only viable option is to downscale operations to a level that is manageable. This means reducing the size of their farming activities to ensure that they can guarantee sales for all the products they produce, thus maintaining financial stability in a challenging market environment.

The speaker recognizes the pressing issues within the agricultural sector, stating, "I can see the issue. I know exactly what the issue is and I know where you’d take it forward." However, they feel limited in their ability to effect change due to a lack of investment, saying, "without the investment or money to back what requires doing, it’s a waste of time." They then discuss the stability of their organization, noting, "The stability in [org name] is fine," but contrasting this with the "disastrous" state of agriculture, emphasizing that without farmers and a reliable supply of potatoes, their organization cannot maintain stability. This highlights the critical need for financial support and investment in the agricultural sector to ensure its resilience and sustainability.

The speaker expresses a deep concern regarding the financial viability of the farming industry in the UK, particularly in the aftermath of Brexit. They note that while their organization ([org name]) is managing to operate profitably, the underlying issue remains that without a robust farming sector, the organization itself cannot sustain its business model. This highlights the precarious nature of agriculture in the current economic climate, where external factors such as Brexit are creating significant risks for farmers, potentially leading to a decline in agricultural productivity and stability.
From the [org name] point of view, basically, I’m getting more growers on board and spreading the risk out to more growers. So, the more growers we get, the less at risk we are.
The contingency plan for the farm side of things is basically reduce what I’m doing, because I cannot risk the losses. So, I’m actually downscaling what we’re doing.

So, you’re aware of this issue but you might not be in a position personally to do much about it? Exactly. I can see the issue. I know exactly what the issue is and I know where you’d take it forward.
The stability in [org name] is fine. The stability in agriculture and farming is disastrous.
Without the farmers and the potatoes, and supply what ever you’re doing, we’re not very stable. The problem is, manufacturing full stop.

The discussion highlights the precarious situation facing the agricultural industry, particularly the reliance on manufacturers for the viability of farming operations. The speaker's concern that "if all the manufacturers stop, it’ll kill it" underscores the critical need for a stable processing capacity to support farmers. The subsequent inquiry about the general consensus among industry stakeholders reflects an effort to understand the broader challenges and explore collaborative solutions. This context is essential for framing the ongoing research aimed at identifying common issues and potential strategies to bolster the agricultural sector.

The discussion highlights a critical point about the agricultural supply chain: if there were increased investments in food manufacturing, it would enable farmers to supply these firms more effectively. The speaker argues that not only is investment necessary, but the structure of the food chain itself must be simplified. By reducing the number of players involved, farmers can retain a larger share of the profits, which is essential for their sustainability. This approach aims to create a more equitable system where the financial benefits flow back to the farmers, addressing the ongoing issues of profitability and market volatility in the agricultural sector.

The speaker envisions a future where sustainability is paramount in the food system. They aim to expand their organization by bringing more farmers on board, thereby increasing the collective benefits for all members. A key initiative is the introduction of a 7.5kg bag line, which represents a step towards getting closer to the customer and reducing dependency on factories. This approach is intended to create a more direct supply chain, ultimately allowing for a process that delivers produce straight from the farm to the end customer. By doing so, they hope to enhance profitability for farmers and ensure that the financial benefits of their work are maximized.

The speaker argues that significant changes are necessary at the government level to prioritize local agriculture over imports, stating, "It’s got to come from government level really, to say, ‘No, no more.’ Or the supermarkets, the customers." They acknowledge the negative impacts of COVID but also point out that some local outlets, like farm shops, have thrived during this time, indicating a shift in consumer preferences towards local produce. This dual perspective illustrates the challenges and opportunities within the agricultural landscape post-COVID.

Yeah. I think there are two-three solutions to the problem. One, we need to be sourcing more locally and supporting more local businesses – that’s a must in every sector we go to. I think we need to allow the money to come down the food chain, to get it back. And these food miles are absolutely nuts. This perspective aligns with the organization's goal of cutting out the middleman and ensuring that more profits return to the farmers, ultimately fostering a more sustainable and efficient food system.
If all the manufacturers stop, it’ll kill it. And that’s all very worrying.
So, there needs to be investment down the food chain, but also making those food chains shorter, as short as possible?
I think sustainability is the key to anything. If we don’t have sustainability, we’ve got problems.
The closer to the customer we get, the more we’ll get back to the farm.
We need to be sourcing more locally and supporting more local businesses – that’s a must in every sector we go to.
